2020-02-05 03:08:53

https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-java-skeleton/issues/43

☝️ Can some one take care of this?

MikeEcho (https://github.com/MikeEcho)
#43 Person class doesn't exist
<p>While following the Cucumber School Online tutorial (<a href="https://school.cucumber.io/enrollments">https://school.cucumber.io/enrollments</a>, "Fundamentals of BDD (Java)"), I was not able to progress past the point where the <code>Person</code> class began to be used to model the domain. I searched the repo that I cloned (the latest version), and it appears that class doesn't exist.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-java-skeleton">cucumber/cucumber-java-skeleton</a>
✔️ matt-SmartBear

Federico Iachetti
2020-02-07 04:30:41

Federico Iachetti
2020-02-07 04:31:03

that way it's easier to see at a glance what changes the commit provides

Federico Iachetti
2020-02-07 04:32:51

mpkorstanje
2020-02-07 04:44:50

*Thread Reply:* If you finish your PR's quickly they won't be long running.

mpkorstanje
2020-02-07 04:45:10

*Thread Reply:* So if you apply a WIP limit of say 3 it shouldn't be a big problem.

mpkorstanje
2020-02-07 04:45:37

*Thread Reply:* I guess that should be a PRIP limit. 😄

matt-SmartBear
2020-02-07 04:46:09

*Thread Reply:* 👍

Federico Iachetti
2020-02-07 04:46:28

*Thread Reply:* what does a WIP limit means?

Federico Iachetti
2020-02-07 04:46:38

*Thread Reply:* (not familiar with that feature)

matt-SmartBear
2020-02-07 04:47:15

*Thread Reply:* Work In Progress

matt-SmartBear
2020-02-07 04:47:40

*Thread Reply:* https://kanbanzone.com/kanban-resources/kanban-wip-limits/

Kanban Zone
Kanban WIP (Work in Progress) Limits | Kanban Zone
Using Kanban WIP Limits (Work in Progress) will Improve productivity, provide focus and manage the flow of your work.
Original URL: https://kanbanzone.com/kanban-resources/kanban-wip-limits/
mpkorstanje
2020-02-07 04:49:05

*Thread Reply:* Work in Progress Limit.

You tell yourself that if you have 3 things in progress you must finish these one of these before starting something new.

It's a good way for getting things done. Though it does mean that you occasionally have to chase people down if you're waiting for a response.

rluba/hamjest
<p>A JavaScript implementation of Hamcrest</p>
Stars
<p>41</p>
Language
<p>JavaScript</p>
<a href="https://github.com/rluba/hamjest">rluba/hamjest</a>
matt-SmartBear

2020-02-07 05:09:50

matt-SmartBear
2020-02-07 05:10:04

const { assertThat } = require('hamjest')

const a = {} a.prop = 5

matt-SmartBear

Federico Iachetti

quick note .... on 02.06 there is this line: Instead of writing a note on our TODO list, let's write another scenario that shouts a different message. It will fail, reminding us we need to find a solution that doesn't rely on hard-coding the message.

Federico Iachetti
2020-02-07 05:31:10

On the JS version I removed the second sentence, because we have this line right after: Now when we come back to this code, we can just run the tests and Cucumber will remind us what we need to do next. We're done for today!

Federico Iachetti
2020-02-07 05:31:39

and that line prompts a cucumber run which shows the tests failing at that point

Federico Iachetti
2020-02-07 05:32:09

so I found the line "It wil fail ..." redundant

Federico Iachetti
2020-02-07 05:32:19

do you have any thoughts on this?

matt-SmartBear
2020-02-07 05:33:35

I like having both, because the first paragraph needs it to explain why we’re doing it.

matt-SmartBear
2020-02-07 05:33:56

then the second paragraph makes a more general point about leaning on Cucumber

matt-SmartBear
2020-02-07 05:34:18

I’m not sure if we need to actually run cucumber to show it failing at this point

matt-SmartBear
2020-02-07 05:34:25

we could, I guess.

Federico Iachetti
2020-02-07 05:34:30

so, the change I'd make then is this: ```shot::[3] Instead of writing a note on our TODO list, let's write another scenario that shouts a different message.

[source,gherkin]

Feature: Hear shout Scenario: Listener is within range Given Lucy is located 15m from Sean When Sean shouts "free bagels at Sean's" Then Lucy hears Sean's message

Scenario: Listener hears a different message Given Lucy is 15m from Sean When Sean shouts "Free coffee!"

Then Lucy hears Sean's message

shot::[4] It fails, reminding us we need to find a solution that doesn't rely on hard-coding the message. Now when we come back to this code, we can just run the tests and Cucumber will remind us what we need to do next. We're done for today!

[source,bash]

$ npm test```

seb

I’ve got some concerns about section 3.5 The parameter names in the Given stepdef are the actual person’s name. Since we’re trying to emphasise that the name is parameterised, this seems confusing.

matt-SmartBear

mattwynne (https://github.com/mattwynne)
#10 Chapter 03 draft (Ruby only)
<p>This is my draft of the Ccumber Expressions chapter.</p> <p>Seb, I'd appreciate you reading it through to see there's anything we could explain better.</p> <p>I'm afraid you'll need to build it locally to read it in preview mode - we're not building branches at the moment.</p> <pre><code>git checkout chapter-o3-first-draft bundle install # if you haven't done that already bundle exec rake open public/index.ruby.html#_expressing_yourself </code></pre> <p>If you're happy with it you can merge it to master (I'd use "squash and merge" as there are lots of noisy commits here)</p>
Reviewers
@iachettifederico, @sebrose
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber-school/fundamentals-of-bdd">cucumber-school/fundamentals-of-bdd</a>
seb
2020-02-10 04:43:32

Suggestion (06-sketch-out-parameter-type): Given("{person} is located/standing {int} metre(s) from Sean") do |named_person, distance| named_person.move_to(distance) end

seb
2020-02-10 04:47:36

Suggestion 1 (07-add-person-parameter): Given("{person} is located/standing {int} metre(s) from {person}") do |named_person1, distance, named_person2| @lucy = named_person1 @sean = named_person2 @lucy.move_to(distance) end

seb
2020-02-10 04:48:45

Suggestion 2 (07-add-person-parameter): Given("{person} is located/standing {int} metre(s) from {person}") do |named_person1, distance, named_person2| @listener = named_person1 @shouter = named_person2 @listener.move_to(distance) end

Federico Iachetti
2020-02-15 18:19:49

https://github.com/cucumber-school/fundamentals-of-bdd/blob/master/content/02/02.03/script.java.adoc

content/02/02.03/script.java.adoc
<pre><code>The easiest way to get started with Cucumber for Java is to use a template project with a build script that sets everything up correctly. shot::[1] You can download this template project from GitHub. Open your web browser and go to the “Cucumber Java Skeleton” project on GitHub. If you’re comfortable with Git you can just clone the project. If you’re new to Git, don’t worry, we’ll download a zip file instead. Click Releases,shot::[2] then download the most recent zip file that starts with a “v”.shot::[3] // If you’re on Windows, click the zip file to download it. If you’re on “OS ten” // or Linux, just copy the link and download it with “wget”. shot::[4] On Windows, extract the zip file by double clicking on it. -Or if you’re on OS ten or Linux, extract it with the unzip command. shot::[5] After extracting the zip file, we’ll rename the directory to “shouty”. shot::[6] In your shell, cd into the shouty directory. shot::[7] The template project contains Maven and Ant build scripts that makes it easier to get started with Cucumber for Java. We’ll be using Maven, so if you haven’t installed that already, now is a good time to do that. shot::[8] Let’s take a look at what else is in this project. [source,bash] ---- $ tree . ├── build.gradle ├── gradle │   └── wrapper │   ├── gradle-wrapper.jar │   └── gradle-wrapper.properties ├── gradlew ├── gradlew.bat ├── LICENCE ├── mvnw ├── mvnw.cmd ├── pom.xml ├── README.md └── src ├── main │   └── java │   └── io │   └── cucumber │   └── skeleton │   └── Belly.java └── test ├── java │   └── io │   └── cucumber │   └── skeleton │   ├── RunCucumberTest.java │   └── StepDefinitions.java └── resources └── io └── cucumber └── skeleton └── belly.feature 17 directories, 14 files ---- There is a main directory for our application code,shot::[9] and a test directory for our test code.shot::[10] Let’s remove some of the files that come with the project. Remove `Belly.java`,shot::[11] `StepDefinitions.java` shot::[12] and `belly.feature`.shot::[13] [source,bash] ---- $ rm src/main/java/io/cucumber/skeleton/Belly.java $ rm src/test/java/io/cucumber/skeleton/StepDefinitions.java $ rm src/test/resources/io/cucumber/skeleton/belly.feature ---- shot::[14] Now we have a bare bones project. We’ll be building it from the ground up so you can see what is going on. [source,bash] ---- $ tree . ├── build.gradle ├── gradle │   └── wrapper │   ├── gradle-wrapper.jar │   └── gradle-wrapper.properties ├── gradlew ├── gradlew.bat ├── LICENCE ├── mvnw ├── mvnw.cmd ├── pom.xml ├── README.md └── src ├── main │   └── java │   └── io │   └── cucumber │   └── skeleton └── test ├── java │   └── io │   └── cucumber │   └── skeleton │   └── RunCucumberTest.java └── resources └── io └── cucumber └── skeleton 17 directories, 11 files ---- Before we open the project in our IDE we are going to modify the name of the application. shot::[15] Open pom.xml and change the group ID,shot::[16] artifact ID shot::[17] and name. shot::[18] We are ready to start coding! We are going to use IntelliJ IDEA Community Edition because it has really nice Cucumber integration built-in.shot::[19] If you prefer to use a different IDE such as Eclipse, that is fine too. // To open the project in InteliJ, just open the pom.xml file. // Before we create any files, let’s rename the package from skeleton to shouty. In // InteliJ you can rename it via the Refactor menu. Now we’re ready to create our first feature file. shot::[21] [source,ruby] ---- $ bundle exec cucumber 0 scenarios 0 steps 0m0.000s ---- </code></pre>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber-school/fundamentals-of-bdd">cucumber-school/fundamentals-of-bdd</a>

*Thread Reply:* If you edit the run configuration add --strict.

If you add it to the Cucumber template (under templates) it will be applied to all future run configuration.

2020-02-17 05:41:01

2020-02-17 05:46:25

*Thread Reply:* Note that this will make skipped scenarios fail if they don't have steps.

Not sure if the teaching material can accomodate this.

Federico Iachetti
2020-02-17 07:18:44

Regarding the Java version, I made some decisions that diverge from the Ruby and JS versions

Federico Iachetti
2020-02-17 07:19:38

since Java is a compiled lang and IntelliJ underline compilation errors before compiling, I switched the order of some shots

Federico Iachetti
2020-02-17 07:20:07

I didn't think it'd make sense to run a scenario when the IDE is actually telling you it will fail

Federico Iachetti
2020-02-17 07:20:23

I think this is more aligned with how Java development is done

matt-SmartBear
2020-02-17 07:20:32

Federico Iachetti

Federico Iachetti
2020-02-17 07:21:38

these changes are reflected on the Script, but not yet on the code

matt-SmartBear
2020-02-17 07:39:38

Federico Iachetti
2020-02-17 07:53:59

Federico Iachetti
2020-02-17 07:54:59

the method to move a Person to a different distance was called setLocation instead of moveTo

Federico Iachetti
2020-02-17 07:55:38

and the implementation of the Given step was to move Lucy to distance and Sean to 0

Federico Iachetti
2020-02-17 07:56:18

in the Rb and JS versions, we create the 2 People and then we move Lucy

seb
2020-02-19 08:35:22
  1. “Or if you’re on OS ten or Linux, extract it with the unzip command.” - OS ten -> Macos
  2. “In InteliJ you can rename it via the Refactor menu.” - did this work for you?
  3. “Let’s create our first feature file. Call the file hear_shout.feature. The first file we are going to create is a feature file where we will write our first scenario. Create a file called hear_shout.feature in the shouty directory under resources.” Seems like a repetition
  4. “Given Lucy is located 15m from Sean” should use “metres” not “m” (2.1 and 2.3): “Given Lucy is located 15 metres from Sean”
  5. “In order to send instructions to Sean from the second step, we’ve stored him in an instance variable” - isn’t this a refactor step, moving lucy and sean from local variables to instance variables?
  6. “java.lang.AssertionError: expected:<[null]> but was:<null>” is shown twice (2.2 and 2.3), but it should be “java.lang.AssertionError: expected:<[“free bagels at Sean’s”]> but was:<null>”
  7. “we got an empty Array back from the messages_heard method” - no, we got a null
Federico Iachetti
2020-02-19 11:51:30
  1. I like it
  2. Yep, it worked
  3. I'll look into this one after work ... I probably messed that part up
  4. I used "15m" because is what we used on the Ruby and JS versions. It was "metres" initially and @matt-SmartBear changed it to "15m" (I assumed it was for simplicity). I think if we change this in the Java we need to change it in the Ruby and JS version (not sure it's worth it for this chapter since we only reference the number here)
  5. I'm not very well versed in IntelliJ. If you say it can be done with a refactor, I think that's the best way to do it. Please feel free to change all the instances of these kinds of things you find without even telling me (I'll say yes to al of them)
  6. I might've pasted the wrong thing there, I'll change it
  7. Good catch
Federico Iachetti
2020-02-19 11:51:43

I'll make those changes tonight after work

2020-02-28 05:42:37

matt-SmartBear
2020-02-28 05:48:35

@gaspar I noticed that in the script, there are less snippets of code included than in the other ones. Was this deliberate? Our idea is to make the script readable enough that we can show it below the video, like a transcript, so showing code snippets in context can be useful.

gaspar
2020-02-28 05:53:29

@matt-SmartBear I have also noticed that. Two reasons:

  1. I tried to include only those snippets that the one who makes the demo has to enter it actually and skipped the ones that were automatically generated by the tooling. Good question though, maybe you are right and if someone would like to review the scripts, the automatic parts should also be included.
  2. In the ruby it was easy to insert the test result into the script, because it is text-based. In .NET/Visual Studio, it is more a graphical result. I don't know how to solve this really.
matt-SmartBear
2020-02-28 06:05:55

Yeah, for (2) we could use screenshots potentially, but maybe it doesn’t matter too much.

gaspar
2020-03-20 00:58:35

Back at work on cucumber school today.

gaspar
2020-03-20 01:00:14

I needed to make a back-merge from master to "specflow"... I know it makes the history more messy, but I wanted to avoid that I "copy" some non-recent stuff from the other platforms.

gaspar
2020-03-20 01:24:42

@matt-SmartBear Fundamental question: I have seen that in the Java version, you call the stepdef class as "StepDefinitions". In SpecFlow the common convention is to call this class "Steps" but that is kind of wrong. Should I follow the (bad) convention and call it "Steps" or the cleaner "StepDefinitions"?

matt-SmartBear
2020-03-20 03:00:30

*Thread Reply:* Most of the people watching these videos are probably not aware of existing conventions, so I think you are free to make up new ones.

matt-SmartBear
2020-03-20 03:00:46

*Thread Reply:* Lead the next generation to better conventions!

matt-SmartBear
2020-03-20 03:01:42

*Thread Reply:* In terms of learning, it’s probably making things clearer to call in by something ‘unconventional’ but more clear, and then once they have climbed the learning curve, they’ll be able to navigate a more conventional codebase with more confusing names.

gaspar
2020-03-20 03:05:03

*Thread Reply:* Ack. Let's go for StepDefinitions and make the world better 🙂

gaspar
2020-03-20 01:36:54

@matt-SmartBear other: many .net devs use a tool "ReSharper" to improve the VS refactoring experience. The things we need in this videos are also in normal VS as well tough. Shall I swith off ReSharper and use the standard VS features?

matt-SmartBear
2020-03-20 03:02:12

*Thread Reply:* Yeah, I don’t see why not.

matt-SmartBear
2020-03-20 03:02:41

*Thread Reply:* I would call it out explicitly in one of the early videos.

matt-SmartBear
2020-03-20 03:02:54

matt-SmartBear
2020-03-20 03:03:16

*Thread Reply:* Just to be clear to someone who doens’t know what it is why you have all these extra superpowers in your Visual Studio

gaspar
2020-03-20 03:08:31

Probably the ones who have R# anyway know the special refactoring features of it. So right now I will try without R# (I anyway need to re-record 2.4 because of the StepDefinitions class name and another smaller thing I missed, so it does not cause extra efforts.)

@matt-SmartBear In 02.04/script.java.adoc line 20-21 we seem to be using the apostrophe inconsistently. (' vs ’ -- not that visible here, but the first one is the ASCII, the other one is the Unicode, slightly more styled. When Sean shouts "free bagels at Sean's" Then Lucy hears Sean’s message Is this intentional? Because when not, I would revert them back to the ASCII one for SpecFlow.

gaspar
2020-03-20 04:13:59

*Thread Reply:* Yes, I know about it and have seen the usage, but I somehow haven't got the right way to use it conveniently. As I need to work parallel on two branches (specflow and chapter-02-code-dotnet), to avoid continuos switching between branches, I cloned the repo two times. But this means that if I would need to render the full script, I would need to push and pull the code to the same branch. Also having a full overview inside the adoc without the need of rendering is more useful for now. I don't know.

matt-SmartBear
2020-03-20 04:14:27

matt-SmartBear
2020-03-20 04:14:58

*Thread Reply:* basically have one clone for the script branch from GitHub, and another clone of that local repo next door for the code branch

matt-SmartBear
2020-03-20 04:15:23

*Thread Reply:* so you only have to push between folders on disk when you change the code storyboard

gaspar
2020-03-20 04:32:34

@matt-SmartBear The first version of 02.05 dotnet script is pushed. https://github.com/cucumber-school/bdd-with-cucumber/blob/specflow/content/02/02.05/script.dotnet.adoc

content/02/02.05/script.dotnet.adoc
<p>``` include::./title.adoc[]</p> <p>//// Overview: <em>* Automate: Given Lucy is located 15m from Sean (create Person class) *</em> Automate: When Sean shouts "free bagels at Sean's" (move declarations to instance field) ** Automate: Then Lucy hears Sean’s message (add assertion) ////</p> <p>// <strong><em>*</strong> Automate: Given Lucy is located 15m from Sean (create Person class) <strong></em>*</strong></p> <p>shot::[1] Now that we have the step definitions matching, we can start working on our solution. We like to use our scenarios to <em>guide</em> our development, so we'll start designing the objects we'll need by sketching out some code in our step definitions.</p> <p>The scenario will be failing while we do this, but we should see the error messages gradually progressing as we drive out the interface to our object model.</p> <p>Our next goal is for the scenario to fail because we need to implement the actual business logic. <em>Then</em> we can work on changing the business logic inside our objects to make it pass.</p> <p>.StepDefinitions.cs</p> <h2>[source,csharp]</h2> <p>[Binding] public class StepDefinitions { [Given(@"Lucy is located (.**)m from Sean")] public void GivenLucyIsLocatedMFromSean(int distance) { throw new PendingStepException(); }</p> <pre><code>[When(@"Sean shouts ""([^""]**)""")] public void WhenSeanShouts(string p0) { throw new PendingStepException(); } [Then(@"Lucy hears Sean’s message")] public void ThenLucyHearsSeanSMessage() { throw new PendingStepException(); } </code></pre> <h2>}</h2> <p>To implement the first step, we need to create a couple of <code>Person</code> objects, one for Lucy shot::[2] and one for Sean.shot::[3]</p> <h2>[source,csharp]</h2> <p>[Given(@"Lucy is located (.**)m from Sean")] public void GivenLucyIsLocatedMFromSean(int distance) { var lucy = new Person(); var sean = new Person();</p> <pre><code>// ... </code></pre> <h2>}</h2> <p>Then we create the <code>Person</code> class into our production project to remove the errors.shot::[4] To make it visible for the SpecFlow project, shot::[5] we need to make it <em>public</em>.</p> <h2>[source,csharp]</h2> <p>namespace Shouty { public class Person { }</p> <h2>}</h2> <p>shot::[6] In order to complete the step defintion for the <em>Given</em> step, we need to specify the distance between Lucy and Sean.</p> <p>video::02.05.animation.mp4[]</p> <p>To keep things simple, we're going to assume all people are situated on a line: a one-dimensional co-ordinate system. We can always introduce proper geo-locations later. We'll place Sean in the centre, and Lucy 15 metres away from Sean.</p> <p>This might not be the design we'll end up with once this is all working, but it's a decent place to start.</p> <p>shot::[7]We can implement our simple distance concept by introducing a <code>MoveTo</code> method like this:shot::[8]</p> <h2>[source,csharp]</h2> <p>[Given(@"Lucy is located (.**)m from Sean")] public void GivenLucyIsLocatedMFromSean(int distance) { var lucy = new Person(); var sean = new Person(); lucy.MoveTo(distance);</p> <pre><code>throw new PendingStepException(); </code></pre> <h2>}</h2> <p>We have two instances of person, one representing Lucy, shot::[9]and one representing Sean. shot::[10]Then we call a method to move Lucy to the position specified in the scenario.shot::[11]</p> <p>As this seems to be complete like this, we can remove the pending exception.shot::[12]</p> <p>There is no <code>MoveTo</code> method yet, shot::[13] so Visual Studio reports a compilation error. To fix it, we can create the method on the <code>Person</code> class, shot::[14] but at this stage we don't bother with the correct implementation. shot::[15] It is enough if it compiles, so an empty method is just fine for now.</p> <h2>[source,csharp]</h2> <p>namespace Shouty { public class Person { public void MoveTo(int distance) { } }</p> <h2>}</h2> <p>shot::[16] When we run the scenario, the first step should be passing! The easiest way to see this is to open the test output by clicking on the "Open additional output for this result" link shot::[17] and check the "Standard Output" section. Here you can see all steps executed by SpecFlow with their results. The first step is "done" shot::[18] and the two others are still pending shot::[19].</p> <h2>[source,bash]</h2> <p>Given Lucy is located 15m from Sean -&gt; done: StepDefinitions.GivenLucyIsLocatedMFromSean(15) (0.0s) When Sean shouts "free bagels at Sean's" -&gt; pending: StepDefinitions.WhenSeanShouts("free bagels at Se...") Then Lucy hears Sean’s message</p> <h2>-&gt; skipped because of previous errors</h2> <p>We're making progress!</p> <p>We'll keep working like this until we see the scenario failing for the right reasons.</p> <p>// <strong><em>*</strong> Automate: When Sean shouts "free bagels at Sean's" (move declarations to instance field) <strong></em>*</strong></p> <p>shot::[20] In the second step definition, we want to tell Sean to shout something.</p> <p>shot::[21] In order to send instructions to Sean from the second step, we need to store him in an <em>instance field</em>, so that he'll be accessible from all of our step definitions. Let's move both declarations up to class level together with the initializations. shot::[22] </p> <p>shot::[23] In the <code>When</code> step, we're capturing Sean's message using shot::[24] <em>this</em> regular expression pattern that is mapped to the parameter shot::[25] <code>p0</code>. Let's give it a more meaningful name.shot::[26] Don't worry if the regular expression pattern sounds unfamiliar to you, we will look at that in detail in the next chapter.</p> <p>And now we can now tell Sean to <em>shout</em> the message: shot::[27]</p> <h2>[source,csharp]</h2> <p>[Binding] public class StepDefinitions { private Person lucy = new Person(); private Person sean = new Person();</p> <pre><code>//... [When(@"Sean shouts ""([^""]**)""")] public void WhenSeanShouts(string message) { sean.Shout(message); } //... </code></pre> <h2>}</h2> <p>We eliminate the compilation error by implementing the <code>Shout</code> method in the <code>Person</code> class. shot::[28]</p> <h2>[source,csharp]</h2> <p>namespace Shouty { public class Person { public void MoveTo(int distance) { }</p> <pre><code> public void Shout(string message) { } } </code></pre> <h2>}</h2> <p>When we run the scenarion again, shot::[29] the second step shot::[30] is also passing!.</p> <h2>[source,bash]</h2> <p>Given Lucy is located 15m from Sean -&gt; done: StepDefinitions.GivenLucyIsLocatedMFromSean(15) (0.0s) When Sean shouts "free bagels at Sean's" -&gt; done: StepDefinitions.WhenSeanShouts("free bagels at Se...") (0.0s) Then Lucy hears Sean’s message</p> <h2>-&gt; pending: StepDefinitions.ThenLucyHearsSeanSMessage()</h2> <p>// <strong><em>*</strong> Automate: Then Lucy hears Sean’s message (add assertion) <strong></em>*</strong></p> <p>shot::[31] The last step definition is where we implement a check, or assertion. We'll verify that what Lucy has heard is exactly the same as what Sean shouted.</p> <p>Once again we're going to write the code we wish we had. shot::[32] In that we are going to use an assertion from the <code>Xunit</code> library, so we need to add the neccessary namespace usages.</p> <p>shot::[33]</p> <h2>[source,csharp]</h2> <p>[Then(@"Lucy hears Sean's message")] public void ThenLucyHearsSeanSMessage() { Assert.Contains(messageFromSean, lucy.GetMessagesHeard());</p> <h2>}</h2> <p>So we need a way to ask Lucy what messages she has heard, and we also need to know what it was that Sean shouted.</p> <p>We can record what Sean shouts by storing it in an instance field as the <code>When</code> step runs. shot::[34] shot::[35] This is a common pattern to use in SpecFlow step definitions when you don't want to repeat the same test data in different parts of a scenario. Now we can use that in the assertion check. shot::[36]</p> <h2>[source,csharp]</h2> <p>[When(@"Sean shouts ""([^""]**)""")] public void WhenSeanShouts(string message) { sean.Shout(message); messageFromSean = message;</p> <h2>}</h2> <p>We also need to add a <code>GetMessagesHeard</code> method to our Person class.shot::[37] Let's do that now, we'll just return null for now.shot::[38]</p> <h2>[source,csharp]</h2> <p>public class Person { public void MoveTo(int distance) { }</p> <pre><code>public void Shout(string message) { } public IList&amp;lt;string&amp;gt; GetMessagesHeard() { return null; } </code></pre> <h2>}</h2> <p>...and watch SpecFlow run the tests again.shot…</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber-school/bdd-with-cucumber">cucumber-school/bdd-with-cucumber</a>

matt-SmartBear
2020-03-23 02:57:56

*Thread Reply:* Yeah. I want to do trunk-based dev, but what I was struggling with was a way for people to easily feed back on a set of changes. It seemed to me that a merged PR might be useful in that you can still use GitHub’s PR tooling for commenting on lines etc. But we’ve only tried that out for one episode and TBH I think Seb just left me comments in Slack somewhere. So maybe I’m overdoing it!

matt-SmartBear
2020-03-24 01:19:15

@Federico Iachetti @gaspar @seb I added the ability to annotate shots - the text you pass as the second parameter to the shot macro will be displayed as hover text in the rendered script. I’m hoping this will help us to reduce confusion a bit in hand-offs and when reviewing scripts.

It’s not mandatory, but it could be helpful where it’s not necessarily obvious from context what the shot is supposed to display.

See https://github.com/cucumber-school/bdd-with-cucumber/pull/14

👍 gaspar

Regular expressions are sometimes accused of being a write-only language. Learn how to clarify your patterns with Ruby's extended regex syntax!

*Thread Reply:* The code in the branch looks correct: https://github.com/cucumber-school/bdd-with-cucumber/blob/chapter-02-code-java/shouty/src/test/resources/shouty/shout.feature

shouty/src/test/resources/shouty/shout.feature
<pre><code>Feature: Shout Scenario: Listener within range Given Lucy is 15 metres from Sean When Sean shouts "free bagels at Sean's" Then Lucy should hear Sean's message Scenario: Listener hears a different mesage Given Lucy is 15 metres from Sean When Sean shouts "Free coffee!" Then Lucy should hear Sean's message </code></pre>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber-school/bdd-with-cucumber">cucumber-school/bdd-with-cucumber</a>

matt-SmartBear
2020-04-21 04:12:00

@Federico Iachetti @gaspar @seb I added a rake code:branches task which will fail if your set of local code branches is different to origin, because Fede found that the rake code task gets very confused if you don’t have all the code branches locally.

matt-SmartBear
2020-04-21 04:13:15

It could get annoying when you’re hacking on a local code branch, because it just compares revisions at the moment but doesn’t know when you have newer changes locally. (i.e. it would force you to push to origin each time you changed a local code branch).

We will need to iterate on it, but it should guard against bad things happening at least.

seb
2020-04-21 04:14:19

Do both rake tasks still exist? Do we use both of them? Can you document/describe the expected workflow?

matt-SmartBear
2020-04-21 06:47:14

*Thread Reply:* I made docs depend on docs:branches so it will check branches before unrolling the docs.

matt-SmartBear
2020-04-21 06:47:30

*Thread Reply:* So the workflow shouldn’t change, it should just be more robust.

matt-SmartBear
2020-05-20 06:37:05

@seb @Federico Iachetti in the script for 03.05.java we say, when defining a custom parameter type “We need to give it a name which is the name we’ll use inside the curly brackets in our step definition expressions.” but I don’t see that in the code:

@ParameterType("Lucy|Sean") public Person person(String name) { return new Person(name); } Do we need to give it a name? if so, where does it go?

matt-SmartBear
2020-05-20 06:42:40

*Thread Reply:* @mpkorstanje can you help me here? The docs aren’t clear.

matt-SmartBear
2020-05-20 06:42:54

*Thread Reply:* https://cucumber.io/docs/cucumber/cucumber-expressions/

matt-SmartBear
2020-05-20 06:43:58

*Thread Reply:* How do you name a custom parameter type in Java? Does it reflect on the method name? Or do you need to pass something to the annotation?

matt-SmartBear
2020-05-20 06:44:47

*Thread Reply:* The example just uses a single parameter with the regex in it, but the docs then go on to list several arguments. How do you pass those in?

mpkorstanje
2020-05-20 06:45:23

*Thread Reply:* The method name is used as the name of the parameter. You can also use @ParameterType(value="Lucy|Sean",name="person")

matt-SmartBear
2020-05-20 06:45:33

*Thread Reply:* Ah the comments! It says that in the comments!

matt-SmartBear
2020-05-20 06:45:37

*Thread Reply:* Thanks 🙂

mpkorstanje
2020-05-20 06:46:58

*Thread Reply:* 👍

Federico Iachetti
2020-05-25 10:00:19

hey folks, how are you? I'm porting Chapter 4 to ruby (from Java). Following the Java version, I have the following feature file: ```Feature: Shout

Shouty allows users to "hear" other users "shouts" as long as they are close enough to each other.

To do: - only shout to people within a certain distance

Rule: Shouts can be heard by other users

Scenario: Listener hears a message
  Given a person named Lucy
  And a person named Sean
  When Sean shouts "free bagels at Sean's"
  Then Lucy should hear Sean's message

Scenario: Listener hears a different mesage
  Given Lucy is 15 metres from Sean
  When Sean shouts "Free coffee!"```

And when I run bundle exec cucumber I'm getting this error: features/hear_shout.feature: Parser errors: (21:3): expected: #EOF, #TableRow, #DocStringSeparator, #StepLine, #TagLine, #ScenarioLine, #ScenarioOutlineLine, #Comment, #Empty, got 'Rule: Shouts should only be heard if listener is within range' (Cucumber::Core::Gherkin::ParseError) /home/fedex/.rvm/gems/ruby-2.6.5/gems/cucumber-core-3.2.1/lib/cucumber/core/gherkin/parser.rb:34:in `rescue in document' /home/fedex/.rvm/gems/ruby-2.6.5/gems/cucumber-core-3.2.1/lib/cucumber/core/gherkin/parser.rb:28:in `document' /home/fedex/.rvm/gems/ruby-2.6.5/gems/cucumber-core-3.2.1/lib/cucumber/core.rb:30:in `block in parse' /home/fedex/.rvm/gems/ruby-2.6.5/gems/cucumber-core-3.2.1/lib/cucumber/core.rb:29:in `each' /home/fedex/.rvm/gems/ruby-2.6.5/gems/cucumber-core-3.2.1/lib/cucumber/core.rb:29:in `parse' /home/fedex/.rvm/gems/ruby-2.6.5/gems/cucumber-core-3.2.1/lib/cucumber/core.rb:21:in `compile' /home/fedex/.rvm/gems/ruby-2.6.5/gems/cucumber-3.1.2/lib/cucumber/runtime.rb:75:in `run!' /home/fedex/.rvm/gems/ruby-2.6.5/gems/cucumber-3.1.2/lib/cucumber/cli/main.rb:34:in `execute!' /home/fedex/.rvm/gems/ruby-2.6.5/gems/cucumber-3.1.2/bin/cucumber:9:in `&lt;top (required)&gt;' /home/fedex/.rvm/gems/ruby-2.6.5/bin/cucumber:23:in `load' /home/fedex/.rvm/gems/ruby-2.6.5/bin/cucumber:23:in `&lt;main&gt;' /home/fedex/.rvm/gems/ruby-2.6.5/bin/ruby_executable_hooks:24:in `eval' /home/fedex/.rvm/gems/ruby-2.6.5/bin/ruby_executable_hooks:24:in `&lt;main&gt;' I understand the error (Rule is not Gherkin). Can anyone help me figure this out?

thanks!

matt-SmartBear
2020-05-26 01:32:40

Hi Fede. Rule is new Gherkin syntax. I think you might need the latest RC version of cucumber-ruby to get it. No time to check myself right now but hopefully this clue helps!

Federico Iachetti
2020-05-26 04:32:13

got it, thanks!

matt-SmartBear
2020-05-26 04:36:19

https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#400rc1-2018-09-29

CHANGELOG.md
<p>```</p> <h1>CHANGE LOG</h1> <p>All notable changes to this project will be documented in this file.</p> <p>This project adheres to <a href="http://semver.org">Semantic Versioning</a>.</p> <p>This document is formatted according to the principles of <a href="http://keepachangelog.com">Keep A CHANGELOG</a>.</p> <p>Please visit <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md">cucumber/CONTRIBUTING.md</a> for more info on how to contribute to Cucumber.</p> <hr /> <h2><a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/compare/v4.0.0.rc.5...master">In GIT</a></h2> <h3>Added</h3> <p>** N/A</p> <h3>Changed</h3> <p>** <code>log</code> method can now be called with non-string objects and will run <code>.to_s</code> on them. <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1410">#1410</a></p> <h3>Removed</h3> <p>** N/A</p> <h3>Improved</h3> <p>** Display snippet when using undefined parameter type <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1411">#1411</a></p> <h2><a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/compare/v4.0.0.rc.5...4.0.0.rc.6">4.0.0.rc.6</a></h2> <h3>Changed</h3> <p>** Code snippet for an undefined step with a Doc String will ouput <code>doc_string</code> instead of <code>string</code> in block params (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1401">#1401</a> <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1402">#1402</a> <a href="https://github.com/karamosky">karamosky</a>)</p> <p>** Updated monorepo libraries:</p><ul><li>cucumber-gherkin ~&gt; 13</li><li>cucumber-html-formatter ~&gt; 6</li><li>cucumber-cucumber-expressions ~&gt; 10</li> </ul> <p>** Use <code>cucumber-ruby-core</code> 7.0.0</p> <p>** Use <code>cucumber-ruby-wire</code> 3.0.0</p> <p>** Use <code>body</code> field of attachments</p> <h3>Improved</h3> <p><em>* <code>--out url</code> updates: *</em> supports redirects <em>* use <code>PUT</code> method by default *</em> use a cURL like options (for example: <code>cucumber --out '&lt;http://example.com&gt; -X POST -H Content-Type: json</code>)</p> <h2><a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/compare/v4.0.0.rc.4...4.0.0.rc.5">4.0.0.rc.5</a></h2> <h3>Added</h3> <p>** New html formatter enabled by option <code>--format html --out report.html</code>.</p> <p>** Accept <code>--out URL</code> to POST results to a web server If a URL is used as output, the output will be sent with a POST request. This can be overridden by specifying e.g. <code>http-method=PUT</code> as a query parameter. Other <code>http-</code> prefixed query parameters will be converted to request headers (with the <code>http-</code> prefix stripped off).</p> <h2><a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/compare/v4.0.0.rc.3...4.0.0.rc.4">4.0.0.rc.4</a></h2> <h3>Added</h3> <p><em>* Add <code>message</code>formatter which produces <code>Cucumber::Messages</code> ndjson output. *</em> Comply with [<code>cucumber-compatibility-kit](&lt;https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/tree/master/compatibility-kit&gt;) ** Methods</code>log<code>and</code>attach` can be used in step definitions to attach text or images</p> <h3>Deprecated</h3> <p><em>* <code>--format=json</code> in favor of the <code>message</code> formatter and the stand-alone JSON formatter *</em> <code>puts</code> in step definitions in favor of <code>log</code> (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/issues/897">cucumber#897</a>) ** <code>embed</code> in step definitions in favor of <code>attach</code> (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/issues/897">cucumber#897</a>)</p> <h2><a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/compare/v4.0.0.rc.2...v4.0.0.rc.3">4.0.0.rc.3</a></h2> <h3>Changed</h3> <p>** Update to cucumber-wire 1.1.</p> <h2><a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/compare/v4.0.0.rc.1...v4.0.0.rc.2">4.0.0.rc.2</a></h2> <h3>Added</h3> <p><em>* There is a new methodology in Cucumber for how the auto-loader works *</em> The old <code>load</code> behaviour is now replaced with a newer <code>require</code> behaviour <em>* Cucumber will (From version 4), now auto-load files using the <code>require</code> method *</em> If you wish to alter this, then you can set a top level config option: <code>Cucumber.use_legacy_autoloader</code> <em>* Like most config options, setting this inside a <code>spec_helper.rb</code> or <code>env.rb</code> file is advised *</em> For more information on this change, including why it was made. Please read this <a href="a href=&quot;http://www.google.com&quot;&gt;www.google.com&lt;/a">Blog Post</a> (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1349">#1349</a>, <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1043">#1043</a> <a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">luke-hill</a>)</p> <h3>Changed</h3> <p>** Going forward the minimum ruby version for all cucumber based gems is 2.3 (<a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">luke-hill</a>)</p> <h3>Removed</h3> <p>** Removed Travis publish job for cucumber-pro(a.k.a. jam) (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1350">#1350</a> <a href="https://github.com/luke-hill">luke-hill</a>)</p> <p>** Drop support for JRuby. We may add this back if new versions of protobuf for JRuby start working, or if someone can make the build pass with an older version. All this means is we're ok to make releases while the jruby CI job is failing.</p> <p>(<a href="https://github.com/aslakhellesoy">aslakhellesoy</a>)</p> <p>** Remove <code>dots-formatter introduced in</code>4.0.0rc1`</p> <h3>Fixed</h3> <p><em>* Fix the placeholder expansions in the json formatter (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1361">#1361</a> <a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">brasmusson</a>) *</em> Fix seed printed in cucumber UI to match the seed that was actually used. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1329">#1329</a> <a href="https://github.com/deivid-rodriguez">deivid-rodriguez</a>) ** Make SIGINT/<code>Ctrl+c</code> behavior consistent with SIGTERM/<code>kill</code> behavior - now first invocation causes existing scenario to stop running and jump to <code>at_exit</code>, second invocation causes immediate exit. Before that first invocation only instructed Cucumber to exit after scenario and second invocation caused immediate exit skipping <code>at_exit</code>. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1353">#1353</a> <a href="https://github.com/akostadinov">akostadinov</a>)</p> <h3>Improved</h3> <p>** Filter out any lines containing <code>site_ruby</code> from stacktrace</p> <h2><a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/compare/v3.1.2...v4.0.0.rc.1">4.0.0.rc.1</a> (2018-09-29)</h2> <h3>Added</h3> <p><em>* Added support for new <code>Rule</code> keyword. <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/blob/master/gherkin/CHANGELOG.md#6013---2018-09-25">Read more here.</a> *</em> Added new <code>dots</code> formatter. This is the first step of a larger strategy to move the formatters to a new architecture where they delegate to shared executables via messages.</p> <h3>Changed</h3> <p><em>* Use Gherkin v6. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1313">#1313</a> <a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">brasmusson</a>) *</em> Do not apply Before and After Hooks to Test Cases with no Test Steps. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1311">#1311</a> <a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">brasmusson</a>) <em>* Pass the registry to the Wire plugin. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1309">#1309</a> <a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">brasmusson</a>) *</em> Adapt to using the Gherkin compiler and Pickles in the core. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1309">#1309</a> <a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">brasmusson</a>) <em>* Let the Pretty Formatter use events. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1305">#1305</a> <a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">brasmusson</a>) *</em> Use single quotes in generated template steps (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1323">#1323</a> <a href="https://github.com/acant">acant</a>)</p> <h3>Removed</h3> <p><em>* Remove the support of old style tag expressions. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1314">#1314</a>, <a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">brasmusson</a>) *</em> Remove the Legacy API for Formatters. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1230">#1230</a>, <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/839">#839</a> <a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">brasmusson</a>) <em>* Remove the JSON Pretty Formatter (which was the same as the JSON formatter). (<a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">brasmusson</a>) *</em> Remove the HTML Formatter. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1306">#1306</a> <a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">brasmusson</a>)</p> <h3>Fixed</h3> <p><em>* Wire protocol compatibility for docstrings. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1183">#1183</a>) *</em> Let the Rerun Formatter handle flaky scenarios. (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1310">#1310</a> <a href="https://github.com/brasmusson">brasmusson</a>)</p> <h3>Improved</h3> <p>** Code style changes completed as per …</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>

seb
2020-05-28 02:58:55

@matt-SmartBear could you please review the questions for Ch 3: https://github.com/cucumber-school/bdd-with-cucumber/blob/master/content/03/questions.adoc

content/03/questions.adoc
<pre><code>= Questions for chapter 3 == Lesson 1 === Which of the following statements are true? ** Step definitions translate human-readable scenarios into concrete actions in code - TRUE ** BDD practitioners think of "step definitions" and "automation code" as distinct concepts - TRUE ** Cucumber only supports automation through the user interface - FALSE Answer: A step definition is a piece of code that is called by Cucumber in response to a step in a scenario. You can write any code you like inside a step definition, but we've found it easier to maintain if we keep them short. This leads to step definitions calling automation dedicated automation code to perform concrete actions against the system under construction. That automation code can manipulate the user interface, make a REST call, or drive the domain model directly. === Which of the following statements are true? ** Regular Expressions are exactly the same as Cucumber Expressions - FALSE ** Modern versions of Cucumber only support Cucumber Expressions - FALSE ** Cucumber Expressions are more intimidating than Regular Expressions - FALSE Answer: Regular Expressions are a powerful tool that have been in use in computer science for many decades. They can be hard understand and maintain, so the Cucumber team created a simplified mechanism, called Cucumber Expressions. However, Cucumber remains backwards compatible, so you can use both Regular Expressions and Cucumber Expressions with modern releases of Cucumber. == Lesson 2 === Which of the following will match the Cucumber Expression `Given Lucy is 15 metres from Sean`? ** `lucy is 15 metres from sean` - FALSE ** `Given Lucy is 15 metres from Sean` - FALSE ** `Lucy is 15 metres from Sean` - TRUE ** `Lucy is 15 metres from Sean Smith` - FALSE Answer: Cucumber Expressions look for a match of the whole step text EXCLUDING the Gherkin keyword (Given/When/Then/And/But). The match is case sensitive and matches whitespace as well. == Lesson 3 === Which of the following is NOT a built in Cucumber Expression parameter type? ** float - FALSE ** integer - TRUE ** string - FALSE ** word - FALSE Answer: The Cucumber Expression parameter type that matches an integer is `{int}`, not `{integer}` === Which of the following statements is true? ** You cannot create your own Cucumber Expression parameter types - FALSE ** Cucumber discards the value that matches a Cucumber Expression parameter type - FALSE ** Your step definition code will be passed the value that matched the Cucumber Expression parameter type - TRUE ** Cucumber always passes the matched parameter as a string - FALSE Answer: Cucumber will pass the step definition a parameter for each Cucumber Expression parameter type. Cucumber will attempt to convert the text that matched into a suitable format. Using the `{int}` parameter type will result in a number being passed to the step definition. You can extend the predefined Cucumber Expression parameter types, by creating your own. == Lesson 4 === How can you express in a Cucumber Expression that matching some text is optional? ** Enclose it in square brackets: [] - FALSE ** Enclose it in parentheses: () - TRUE ** Place a question mark after it: ? - FALSE ** Precede it with a slash: / - FALSE Answer: Any text in a Cucumber Expression that is surrounded by parentheses `()` is considered optional. === What does a slash `/` separating words mean in a Cucumber Expression? ** The words are considered alternatives - the Cucumber Expression will match any of them - TRUE ** It doesn't mean anything special - the Cucumber Expression will match the slash as a literal character- FALSE ** The word that follows the slash is considered optional - FALSE Answer: Words in a Cucumber Expression that are separated by a slash `/` are considered alternates. There must be no whitespace between the word and the slash. === Which of the following Cucumber Expressions would match both "it weighed 3 grammes" and "it weighed 1 gramme"? ** "it weighed {int} gramme(s)" - TRUE ** "it weighed 1/3 gramme/s" - FALSE ** "it weighed 1/3 gramme(s)" - TRUE ** "it weighed 1 / 3 gramme(s)" - FALSE ** "it weighed 1/2/3 gramme/grammes" - TRUE Answer: Any text surrounded by parentheses `()` is considered optional. Any words separated by a slash `/` are considered to be alternates. You can find full documentation about Cucumber Expressions at &lt;https://cucumber.io/docs/cucumber/cucumber-expressions/&gt; == Lesson 5 === Java ==== What role do Regular Expressions play in Cucumber Expressions? ** None ** Cucumber Expressions provide a subset of Regular Expression syntax ** Cucumber Expressions are exactly the same as Regular Expressions ** A Regular Expression is used to define the text to be matched when using a custom Parameter Type - TRUE Answer: We use a Regular Expression to specify the text that should be matched when a custom Parameter Type is used in a Cucumber Expression. ==== How would you use the custom Parameter Type defined by the following code? @ParameterType("activated") public Status state(String activationState) { return new Status(activationState); } ** {activated} ** {activationState} ** {state} - TRUE ** {Status} Answer: The name of a custom Parameter Type is defined by the name of the method that is decorated with the `@ParameterType` annotation. === Javascript ==== What role do Regular Expressions play in Cucumber Expressions? ** None ** Cucumber Expressions provide a subset of Regular Expression syntax ** Cucumber Expressions are exactly the same as Regular Expressions ** A Regular Expression is used to define the text to be matched when using a custom Parameter Type - TRUE Answer: We use a Regular Expression to specify the text that should be matched when a custom Parameter Type is used in a Cucumber Expression. ==== How would you use the custom Parameter Type defined by the following code? defineParameterType({ name: 'state', regexp: /activated/, transformer: activationState =&amp;gt; new Status(activationState) }) ** {activated} ** {activationState} ** {state} - TRUE ** {Status} Answer: The name of a custom Parameter Type is defined by the `name` parameter passed to the `defineParameterType` method. === Ruby ==== What role do Regular Expressions play in Cucumber Expressions? ** None ** Cucumber Expressions provide a subset of Regular Expression syntax ** Cucumber Expressions are exactly the same as Regular Expressions ** A Regular Expression is used to define the text to be matched when using a custom Parameter Type - TRUE Answer: We use a Regular Expression to specify the text that should be matched when a custom Parameter Type is used in a Cucumber Expression. ==== How would you use the custom Parameter Type defined by the following code? ParameterType( name: 'state', regexp: /activated/, transformer: -&amp;gt; (activationState) { Status.new(activationState) } ) ** {activated} ** {activationState} ** {state} - TRUE ** {Status} Answer: The name of a custom Parameter Type is defined by the `name` parameter passed to the `ParameterType` method. === C# </code></pre>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber-school/bdd-with-cucumber">cucumber-school/bdd-with-cucumber</a>

internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:797 throw err; ^

Error: Cannot find module '../lib/cli/run.js' Require stack:

  • /home/fedex/cucumber/code/nodemodules/cucumber/bin/cucumber-js at Function.Module.resolveFilename (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:794:15) at Function.Module.load (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:687:27) at Module.require (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:849:19) at require (internal/modules/cjs/helpers.js:74:18) at Object.<anonymous> (/home/fedex/cucumber/code/nodemodules/cucumber/bin/cucumber-js:3:1) at Module.compile (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:956:30) at Object.Module.extensions..js (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:973:10) at Module.load (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:812:32) at Function.Module.load (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:724:14) at Function.Module.runMain (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:1025:10) { code: 'MODULENOTFOUND', requireStack: [ '/home/fedex/cucumber/code/nodemodules/cucumber/bin/cucumber-js' ] } npm ERR! Test failed. See above for more details. This is the line I'm using in the packages file: "cucumber": "cucumber/cucumber-js.git",```
David Goss
2020-06-03 10:13:36

*Thread Reply:* the code in cucumber-js is in TypeScript, there it's looking for the compiled JS in lib which isn't there if you install straight from Git as there's been no build

David Goss
2020-06-03 10:13:53

*Thread Reply:* what i'd probably suggest instead is

  1. clone cucumber-js localy
  2. yarn install or npm install
  3. should then see JS files in lib
  4. npm link
  5. then in your consuming project npm link cucumber
Federico Iachetti
2020-06-03 07:05:04

can anyone help me with this?

seb
2020-06-04 01:12:33

*Thread Reply:* Did you see the response from @David Goss? Were you able to get it to work?

seb
2020-06-08 06:07:37

*Thread Reply:* 1. clone cucumber-js localy

  1. git checkout cck
  2. npm run build-local
  3. yarn install or npm install
  4. should then see JS files in lib
  5. npm link
  6. then in your consuming project npm link cucumber

*Thread Reply:* Could you re-record, please: We can translate this into a Gherkin scenario so that Cucumber can run it. Here’s how that would look.

You can see there are four special keywords being used here. Scenario just tells Cucumber we’re about to describe an example that it can execute. Then you see the lines beginning with Given, When and Then.

matt-SmartBear
2021-02-26 10:44:26

@Arthur there’s some feedback here about the pace of the videos being too quick sometimes: https://cucumberbdd.slack.com/archives/C9C3FSGRE/p1614329246001000?thread_ts=1598610635.041200&cid=C9C3FSGRE

I think @Jo Laing had noticed that as well.

I’ll ask him if there are any specific bits he’s noticed, but can we bear it in mind for future episodes?

Junilu Lacar (https://cucumberbdd.slack.com/team/U01PG0L45EW)
<p>I think it’s great that the course shows the dynamic nature of the feature specs and how they evolve as you incrementally develop the application code. Too often, people think that once a scenario has been written then it’s set in stone. The course shows a valuable lesson in refactoring the feature spec, deleting, extracting, refining, etc. This is awesome. One complaint I have though is that it goes too fast in the recording and I have to often pause and read the code so I can make the connections. I’m a coach who is experienced with this stuff and even I’m having trouble keeping up and digesting the material at the pace it’s being given. I suspect that many important points being made will be lost on beginners. Great material though and I really appreciate the effort put into the course material and explanations. I’m actually learning some new things, too.</p>
Original URL: https://cucumberbdd.slack.com/archives/C9C3FSGRE/p1614329246001000?thread_ts=1598610635.041200&amp;cid=C9C3FSGRE

matt-SmartBear
2021-06-17 11:54:11

@Federico Iachetti I noticed a mistake in the script when doing the audio for 06.04 Ruby (the one about the rerun formatter). I've made a PR so you can see what's changed. I think it will need some re-shoots.

https://github.com/cucumber-school/bdd-with-cucumber/pull/40

<https://github.com/cucumber-school/bdd-with-cucumber/pull/40|#40 Improve script around use of @-sign and rerun formatter>
<p>There seems to have been a misunderstanding of why we use the "@" sign.<br /> We only need it when we run the tests, not when we create the file.</p> <p><a href="https://github.com/iachettifederico">@iachettifederico</a> I think this will need a little bit of re-shooting.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber-school/bdd-with-cucumber">cucumber-school/bdd-with-cucumber</a>

matt-SmartBear

07.04.js feedback (thread)

matt-SmartBear
2021-06-24 12:00:49

*Thread Reply:* in general, the technical shots need to pause a little bit longer on the "end state" so that the user can see what's been typed in. It's generally fine with shots where we write code for them to be speeded up, as long as the shot hangs on the end state for a few moments. What I'm seeing is that the other shots, where we type in a command and watch the output, tend to end very quickly, so it's hard to see what was typed. I'd like those shots of the command prompt activity to be slowed down a bit, to make it easier for people to follow along.

matt-SmartBear
2021-06-24 12:01:08

*Thread Reply:* I dunno if that feedback is actionable enough for you @Arthur, do you need more specific examples or do you know what I mean?

matt-SmartBear
2021-06-24 12:03:02

*Thread Reply:* e.g. around 0:38 the command is entered and then run extremely quickly, and because the output is so long, it pushes the command off the top of the screen. So it's hard for the viewer to see what command was typed in.

matt-SmartBear
2021-06-24 12:04:13

*Thread Reply:* Around 0:41 where we say "down here" we need to linger for longer on the shot where we highlight the code about to be copied.

matt-SmartBear
2021-06-24 12:06:44

*Thread Reply:* 0:57 "We can apply" we should change shot to show the scenario now, instead of waiting until 1:02

matt-SmartBear
2021-06-24 12:08:33

*Thread Reply:* 1:19 "for now" we need to linger for a moment to let the viewer see what code has been written. Even if we need to put a gap in the audio.

matt-SmartBear
2021-06-24 12:09:49

*Thread Reply:* 2:07 I'd linger a little longer here too

matt-SmartBear
2021-06-24 12:10:41

*Thread Reply:* 2:40 add a little pause here too

matt-SmartBear
2021-06-24 12:12:32

*Thread Reply:* 2:52 "right" - change to the next shot now to show the feature file, but pause the clip until around 3:00 as it does now.

matt-SmartBear
2021-06-24 12:14:23

*Thread Reply:* 3:44 pause for a moment before saying "that's better". We need to give the viewer a chance to digest what's just happened before we move on.

matt-SmartBear
2021-06-24 12:15:42

*Thread Reply:* 4:30 pause here to let the viewer see the code that we've written

matt-SmartBear
2021-06-24 12:16:29

*Thread Reply:* 4:43 add a pause before switching shots

matt-SmartBear
2021-06-24 12:17:00

*Thread Reply:* OK done

matt-SmartBear
2021-06-24 12:17:21

*Thread Reply:* @Arthur do you think you can apply the same principles to the Ruby one or would you like similar detailed feedback?

matt-SmartBear
2021-06-24 12:17:35

*Thread Reply:* Sorry if I should have reviewed the shot markers better before you did your edits.

matt-SmartBear
2021-06-24 12:18:02

07.05.js feedback (thread)

matt-SmartBear
2021-06-24 12:25:01

*Thread Reply:* 1:38 "let's split this scenario in two". This is the crux of the lesson, but it goes so fast! I'd like us to slow down a bit. @Federico Iachetti I think it would be better to have:

• a shot where we duplicate the original scenario, twice • a shot where we change the Scenario: name of each of the duplicated scenarios to match what I say in the audio, then clean up the steps to match that intent • a shot where we add a Rule keyword above each one. • "removing the rules from the feature file's free-text description field" we need a shot zooming out to show the whole feature, and deleting the description that we added in the earlier lesson. • @Federico Iachetti I think the Then steps are wrong here - they show an expected 11 credits but that won't be correct now the behaviour has been split into two scenarios. See https://github.com/cucumber-school/bdd-with-cucumber/blob/chapter-07-code-js/features/premium_shouts.feature#L13 - the expected final totals should be 15 and 26

<https://github.com/cucumber-school/bdd-with-cucumber/blob/chapter-07-code-js/features/premium_shouts.feature | premium_shouts.feature>
<pre><code> Rule: Mention the word "buy" and you lose 5 credits. </code></pre>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber-school/bdd-with-cucumber">cucumber-school/bdd-with-cucumber</a>

matt-SmartBear
2021-09-08 12:14:05

matt-SmartBear
2021-09-08 12:14:23

Then the old chapter 9 (acceptance tests vs unit tests) becomes our new chapter 10.

matt-SmartBear
2021-09-08 12:15:11

Does that make sense?

matt-SmartBear
2021-09-08 12:16:10

I realised because the intro says "We finished the lesson on a technical note, showing you how to extract a layer of support code from your step definitions to keep your Cucumber code easy - and cost-effective - to maintain." but we haven't got that bit in our scripts anywhere - that's what needs to happen in chapter 9!

matt-SmartBear
2021-09-08 12:16:17

Let's call our Chapter 9 "Support Code" instead of "Keeping your Automation Code Maintainable" too long-winded.

matt-SmartBear
2021-09-08 12:32:31

Yuya Kazama
2021-11-12 23:45:55

*Thread Reply:* I already created the subscript file. If you’re OK, could you add the subtitle setting?

How to set is on the following page. https://support.google.com/youtube/answer/2734796?hl=en

Thank you for considering.

support.google.com
Add subtitles and captions - YouTube Help
Subtitles and captions allow you to share your videos with a larger audience, including deaf or hard-of-hearing viewers and viewers who speak another language. Learn more about&amp;nbsp;editing or removin

matt-SmartBear
2022-01-24 14:49:27

@Federico Iachetti I'm doing some refactoring in the git repo to allow us to host multiple courses in there.

In doing that, I think i've noticed that some of our code unrolls were out of sync we'd made to the code branches. We added a new commit at the beginning of the chapter-09-code-ruby branch which I don't think we've unrolled.

I'm going to fix it now.

matt-SmartBear
2022-01-25 10:59:15

OK I have almost completed the refactoring of the scripts repo to work for multiple courses.

@gaspar @seb @Federico Iachetti please be aware of this change, it's quite sizeable.

I've added a new directory level under content - one for each course.

The rake html task now iterates the courses as well as the chapters.

The repo is renamed from cucumber-school/bdd-wtih-cucumber to cucumber-school/cripts

The last piece of the puzzle will be to rename all the code storyboard branches to include the course name in the branch name. I am a bit scared of doing this as you'll all have to fix your git setup afterwards and fetch all the new branches to be able to run rake code.

Is anyone working on a code storyboard branch at the moment?

seb
2022-01-25 11:11:45

2022-01-25 11:10:23

2022-01-26 11:15:53

Ok all the new branches are pushed now.

matt-SmartBear
2022-01-26 11:16:03

You can run rake code locally and it should pull them all down for you (once you've pulled the latest version of main )

matt-SmartBear
2022-01-26 11:16:47

Gather
Gather is a video-calling space that lets multiple people hold separate conversations in parallel, walking in and out of those conversations just as easily as they would in real life.
